Deep dive on $MELI ğŸ§ 
If you are interested or invested in Mercado Libre you better read.

First of all MercadoLibre ($MELI) is not just "the Amazon of Latin America." That is a lazy comparison. If we wanna trhow comparison then it is more an Amazon, PayPal and a better version of FedEx rolled into one, operating in one of the most hostile logistical and financial environments on Earth.

The company has evolved from an ecommerce marketplace into a digital infrastructure utility for Latin America, by solving the region's two biggest friction points: moving goods (logistics) and moving money (fintech), in this way it has built a dual engine moat that is exceptionally difficult to replicate.

Lest dissect the Business Model:
$MELI operates two symbiotic businesses that feed each other.

A. Commerce (The "Amazon" Leg)
Marketplace: The core platform matching buyers and sellers.

Mercado EnvÃ­os (Logistics): This is the crown jewel. In a region where mail systems are broken, MELI built its own. By late 2025, they increased fulfillment capacity by 41% YoY, operating their own cargo planes ("Meli Air") and thousands of vans.â€‹
Just one Key Stat -> Fulfillment penetration in Brazil is now over 60%, meaning MELI controls the package from warehouse to door for the majority of sales.â€‹

B. Fintech (The "PayPal + Nubank" Leg)

Mercado Pago: Originally built to process payments on the platform, it is now the largest fintech in LATAM. It processes payments off-platform (QR codes, mobile POS) and offers credit.
Mercado CrÃ©dito (The profit engine): They use data from seller sales and buyer history to underwrite loans that traditional banks won't touch.
Key Stat also here -> As of Q3 2025, the credit portfolio surged 83% YoY to $11.0 billion

1) The Logistics Moat (Irreplicable Scale)
In Latin America, logistics is the barrier to entry. While Amazon Brazil waives fees to attract sellers, they are playing catch up to MELIâ€™s physical infrastructure.â€‹

Speed as a Weapon: MELI offers same day delivery in Argentina and massive next day coverage in Mexico and Brazil. This speed creates a habit forming loop that cheaper competitors (like Shein or Shopee) cannot match on speed and smaller competitors cannot match on cost.â€‹

Consider that, despite inflation, unit shipping costs in Brazil dropped 8% in Q3 2025 due to density efficiency.â€‹

2) The Advertising Kicker (Pure Profit)

This is the hidden (not so much anymore) growth story. Similar to Amazon's evolution, MELI is turning its "real estate" into ad space.
In fact, Advertising revenue grew 63% in Q3 2025.â€‹

Consider here that integration with Google Ad Manager allows them to serve ads platform, turning MELI into a media powerhouse for LATAM.

Basically if you are long MELI, you are shorting Latin American instability. So lets reverse thinking and check how you could lose money investing in $MELI:

1) Credit Blowup: The credit book grew 83% YoY. In a recession, bad loans (NPLs) could spike. Currently, 15-90 day NPLs are stable at 6.8%, but this is a high-wire act. If Brazil's economy turns, this portfolio is the first domino.â€‹

2) Margin Compression: Operating margins dipped to roughly 9.8% in late 2025 because they are spending heavily on free shipping and credit issuance. Wall Street hates margin compression, even if it's for good long term reasons.â€‹

3) Competition: Amazon is "buying" share in Brazil with fee waivers and Asian players (Shein/Temu) are pressure testing MELI on price. (However, MELI's delivery speed remains a firewall against the cross-border players)
